    "lines": [
      "class WeatherSimulator:",
      "    def __init__(self, temperature, humidity):",
      "        self.temperature = temperature",
      "        self.humidity = humidity",
      "        self.weather_conditions = None",
      "    def update_weather(self):",
      "        if self.temperature > 30 and self.humidity > 50:",
      "            self.weather_conditions = 'Thunderstorm'",
      "        elif self.temperature > 20:",
      "            self.weather_conditions = 'Sunny'",
      "        else:",
      "            self.weather_conditions = 'Cold'",
      "    def make_rain(self):",
      "        self.humidity += 20",
      "        self.update_weather()"
    ]
  },

If we artificially set the humidity to 70%, will the weather conditions always correspond to a 'Thunderstorm'?
Explanation: Setting humidity to 70% alone doesn't guarantee 'Thunderstorm' weather conditions, as the occurrence also relies on the temperature being above 30, based on the conditions defined in the method update_weather.
